People usually talk about the casting of Audrey instead of Julie Andrews on this movie. I saw some of the singing performances of Audrey that were dubbed and she is, in fact, sub-par on that point. Would Julie sing better than Audrey? Absolutely. Would she act better than Audrey? I'm not sure she would. This is the first movie I saw with Audrey, and I thought she's a spectacular actress, but I already saw many things with Julie Andrews and, although she's a good actress, I'm not sure the trade-off would be favorable. Past that point, I'm impressed of how much I liked this movie, because musicals usually are boring and extremely cheesy, but this one is very interesting and none of the musical performances were able to annoy me. The plot is interesting, the acting and singing is amazing. I noticed some editing flaws (at least I guess they're flaws, I don't know much about this), but otherwise the movie was perfect and the 3 hours flew by.

This is a huge film in every way. It looks like it used every bit of its then $17M to make. The story based on Shaw's Pygmalion has been transformed with Lerner and Loewe's brilliant score and libretto. A Professor of linguistics has a bet that he can pass off a poor street girl as a society "Lady" only to fall in love with her. Directed by brilliant Hollywood director George Cukor, sumptuous Art Direction from Cecil Beaton and music supervised by André Previn this is probably the last of the big Musicals (made by Warner Brothers not MGM). The only reason for four and a half stars and not 5  is Audrey Hepburn. She is miscast in this version and unfortunately Julie Andrews who was in the West End and Broadway productions was waived aside in favour of Hepburn who's star was on the ascendent at this time. However this was made the same year as Mary Poppins and Andrews won the Academy Award for that role and Hepburn went away  empty handed.  If you can find it playing on the big screen try to catch it in its 70mm version which is a real treat. The film has recently been restored and the sound and vision is truly stunning.

I feel like I should like My Fair Lady.  Maybe not even like it.  Love it.  Sing its praises.  But I can't.  For one, it's nearly three hours long, which is about an hour too long.  Second, the early part of the film languishes from Hepburn trying to unconvincingly pull off a dirty, profane woman when the production never "messes" her up enough for the character.  Third, the direction by Cukor feels entirely ripped off from the stage instead of giving the production a motion picture feel.  Fourth, and here's the big one, the idea of a man "creating" a woman and that woman coming back to him is morally suspect.  Harrison is pompus as Henry Higgins, so much so to make him unlikeable.  Hepburn's Eliza Doolittle is game, but she is hamstrung by a character who doesn't know which way to go.  I expected more from this group.

Adorable, charming, witty, funny, heartwarming - there are many adjectives that go almost perfectly with this fantastic musical of a movie. My Fairy Lady shows a perfectly delightful tale about one woman's struggle to adapt to a higher society and learn how to speak proper English. The whole farce is truly laughable. And there is a great amount of romance that comes with it. Audrey Hepburn will always be remembered as the clumsy, yet really lovable and pretty flower girl, who is gradually becoming a great lady. The songs are splendid and catchy, just as the style of the characters is indisputable.

What stands out most in ''My Fair Lady'' is its rich production value. Everything clicks on the technical side of things. It also features one of Audrey Hepburn's most sterling performances. The romantic element in this film I thought was laughable, though. The entire Hepburn/Harrison relationship was pretty awkward/unpleasant to watch. Nonetheless, a decent movie to see once.

DISCLAIMER: Under no circumstances should you watch this and West Side Story in the same week, month, or year. Hearing the same singing voice coming from Natalie Wood and Audrey Hepburn is just weird. That said, My Fair Lady is a classic musical, and it deserves the status. The songs are memorable, the leads are likable, and there's a sense of spectacle to the whole affair that just screams 'Broadway'. I'm always a bit leery of old musicals because of the excessiveness exhibited by many of them. Here, outside of Alfie Dolittle's draggy song-and-dance numbers, there doesn't seem to be a lot of excess material. And Rex Harrison is probably the ONLY actor who can play Henry Higgins and make him come off as lovable, not just a snotty asshole. It's a bit upsetting that Audrey Hepburn's real singing voice isn't on display, but the songs are all so well-dubbed, it's hard to tell unless you know going in. While I'd argue against Oliver and Sound of Music being considered 'classics', My Fair Lady actually does deserve most of the praise heaped upon it.

Just don't watch it in the same block as West Side Story.
